Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: IA: Query-by-example for Big astronomical Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
While the most significant projects in modern observational astrophysics generate very large data sets, the computational methodology lags behind, and has trouble effectively analyzing these data. Although current and future astronomical surveys will produce the world's largest public databases, the methods to turn these data into scientific discoveries do not yet exist. This project will develop an automatic query-by-example system for classifying galaxies by their similarities to other galaxies, using unsupervised machine learning techniques. This capability does not currently exist and it can substantially enhance the experience and discovery power of digital sky surveys. The project has an educational component, focusing in particular on undergraduate research for under-represented minority students.

Existing, and especially planned, surveys can image billions of galaxies, making the ability to study rare galaxies through computer analysis absolutely essential. These uncommon objects are critical for understanding the most fundamental questions about the early, present, and future universe, as they carry crucial information on the history of the interactions of objects, their formation, and their evolution. The system to be developed will take an image of a certain (normally peculiar) galaxy, identified by the researcher as being of interest, and will search through millions of galaxies to find the visually most similar galaxies to the query galaxy. Because studying unusual galaxies and making scientific conclusions about their nature requires a certain population from which to derive properties that can be compared to other systems, this capability and the resulting listings will greatly increase the ability to make discoveries from sky surveys, optimizing the scientific return of these important and expensive research instruments.

This project connects with existing efforts to attract under-represented minorities, adding more advanced research training in the later years of their undergraduate degree. Studies like this always include opportunities for public outreach, and the team expects to contribute to the forming big data hub in their area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the project was to develop and test algorithms that can identify galaxies that are visually similar to a query galaxy, and therefore can find instances of a certain galaxy of interest in large databases of galaxy images created by digital sky surveys. That is, if an astronomer identifies a galaxy of interest, they can feed that galaxy into a system that searches for more instances of galaxies similar to the query galaxy among millions of galaxy images. The result of the process is a collection of galaxies visually similar to the query galaxy to provide a sufficient dataset that allows to study that specific galaxy type.

The project produced several major outcomes, both in its intellectual merit and broader impact. The query-by-example algorithm was completed and tested, as summarized in two peer-reviewed papers. Several search strategies were tested and compared to identify the most efficient search and similarity measurement strategies. Also, the more recent version of the algorithm uses both photometry and image data to form a hybrid method that combines the visual and photometric data to improve the accuracy. The software has also become public, and the source code is open and freely available through the Astrophysics Source Code Library. The experiments show that, as was expected due to the complex nature of the problem, the algorithm is not fully accurate. However, it reduces the amount of data that needs to be scanned by three orders of magnitude. That is, the algorithm returns to the user a collection of galaxies in which the target galaxies are about three orders of magnitude more frequent compared to a random set of galaxies. That shows that the algorithm can be effective in identifying galaxies that are visually similar to a certain galaxy of interest.

In addition to the algorithm and the software, the project also led to the use of software and automation to create and release several catalogs of galaxies. The first catalog is a catalog of ~3,000,000 SDSS galaxies with annotated broad morphology. That catalog has been released, and is now included in CAS so that astronomers can use it in a convenient manner. Figure 1 shows the catalog as part of CAS, allowing easy queries with the other CAS tables and data.

Another important outcome of the project is a catalog of 186 rare ring galaxy candidates that were detected automatically in PanSTARRS. Figure 2 shows some examples of the detected ring galaxies. The catalog has been published, and researchers can use it to study that rare yet important galaxy type.

Overall, the project led to the publication of 10 peer-reviewed papers published in archived astronomy journals, as well as three American Astronomical Society (AAS) meeting presentations. Additionally, the outcomes were highlighted in AAS Nova and premier mainstream media such as The Atlantic.

 

The project has substantial outcomes in the sense of its broader impact, which was mostly focused on education and inclusion. The inclusion part is done by providing research experience to the students through the course-based research experience model (CRE). The exposure to research is a proven intervention that engages students and increases retention and graduate school attendance in STEM.

The research done in this project involved several undergraduate students, but mainly contributed to the development of these educational methods and to data science hand-on education through astronomy data. It became part of the research-based education developed through another ~$300K grant by the American Association of Colleges and Universities (AAC&U), which in October 2017 turned into a much larger ~$1M project funded by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI). Although just started, the program already affected hundreds of students, with promising preliminary results as evident through formal evaluation. That program now includes 21 faculty members, and impacts the entire college.

An expected outcome of the project is student engagement in research reflected by student publications. The project led to 11 student-authored publications (in addition to astronomy publications mentioned above), and in several cases the students and their work were mentioned in the premier international mainstream media.
